tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: For the chief musician
tn.text: "This is for the director of music to use in worship."

tn.ref: A psalm of the sons of Korah
tn.text: "This is a psalm that the sons of Korah wrote."

tn.ref: you have showed favor to your land
tn.text: Here "land" represents the nation and people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: well-being
tn.text: being** - This refers to a person being happy, healthy and prosperous.

tn.ref: of Jacob
tn.text: Here "Jacob" represents Jacob's descendents, the Israelites. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: you have covered all their sin
tn.text: Here sin that is forgiven is spoken of as if it were covered so that it can not be seen. AT: "you have deliberately forgotten their sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: their sin
tn.text: This writer thought of himself as belonging to God's people. AT: "our sin"

tn.ref: Selah
tn.text: This may be a musical term that tells people how to sing or play their instruments here. Some translations write the Hebrew word, and some translations do not include it. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:003:001|3:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_transliterate]])

tn.ref: You have withdrawn all your wrath
tn.text: God no longer punishing the Israelites is spoken of as if wrath were an object that Yahweh could take away from the Israelites. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you have turned back from your hot anger
tn.text: God no longer being angry with the Israelites is spoken of as if anger were a fire that God from which God turned away. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: God of our salvation
tn.text: The abstract noun "salvation" can be stated as a verb. AT: "God who saves us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: let go of your displeasure with us
tn.text: Asking God to stop being angry with the Israelites is spoken of as if displeasure were an object the writer wants God to let go of. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Will you be angry with us forever? Will you remain angry throughout future generations?
tn.text: The writer uses these questions to emphasize that he is requesting God to stop being angry with them. These rhetorical questions can be translated as a statement. AT: "Please do not stay angry at us forever." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Will you not revive us again?
tn.text: The writer uses a question to emphasize his request to God to make the people of Israel prosper and happy again. AT: "Please make us prosper again." This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Show us your covenant faithfulness
tn.text: The abstract noun "faithfulness" can be stated as an adjective. AT: "Be faithful because of your covenant with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: grant us your salvation
tn.text: The word "by" can be added to indicate this is how the writer wants God to show his faithfulness to his people. The abstract noun "salvation" can be stated as a verb. AT: "by saving us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: make peace with his people
tn.text: "have a peaceful relationship with his people" or "bring peace to his people"

tn.ref: Yet they must not turn again to foolish ways
tn.text: A person changing the way he behaves is spoken of as if he were physically turning to a different direction. AT: "Yet they must not start doing foolish things again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Surely his salvation is near to those
tn.text: God being ready to save someone is spoken of as if salvation were an object that God has placed near someone. AT: "Surely God is ready to save those" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: then glory will remain in our land
tn.text: Here "glory" represents God's presence. AT: "then his glorious presence will remain in our land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness have met together
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) God will be faithful because his covenant and do what he promised to do or 2) God will be faithful because of his covenant and the people will respond by being faithful to him. Either way faithfulness and trustworthiness are spoken of as if they were persons who meet together. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: have met together ... have kissed each other
tn.text: Most likely the speaker is describing a time in the future when God causes the people to prosper again. AT: "will meet together ... will kiss each other"

tn.ref: righteousness and peace have kissed each other
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) the people will do what is right and God will cause the people to live in peace or 2) God will do what is right and will cause the people to live in peace. Either way righteousness and peace are spoken of as if they were persons who kiss each other. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: kissed each other
tn.text: This was a common way for friends to greet each other.

tn.ref: Trustworthiness springs up from the ground
tn.text: The people on earth being faithful to God is spoken of as if trustworthiness were a plant growing out of the ground. AT: "Here on earth, we will be loyal to God" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: righteousness looks down from the sky
tn.text: The writer describes righteousness as a person looking down as God does. AT: "God will look upon us with favor and give us victory" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: Righteousness will go before him and make a way for his footsteps
tn.text: God doing what is right everywhere he goes is spoken of as if righteousness were a person who goes ahead of God and prepares a path for God to walk. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: his footsteps
tn.text: Here "footsteps" represents where God walks. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
